password: To create a strong password, use a mix of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. Avoid using easily guessable information like your name, birthdate, or common words.
phishing: Phishing scams often come as emails or messages that appear to be from legitimate sources. Always double-check the sender's email address and avoid clicking on suspicious links.
hacked: If you suspect your account has been hacked, immediately change your passwords, enable two-factor authentication, and contact your financial institution to secure your accounts.
online shopping: Shop only on secure websites that start with HTTPS. Avoid making purchases over public Wi-Fi and always check your bank statements for unauthorized transactions.
public Wi-Fi: Public Wi-Fi networks are not secure. Avoid accessing sensitive information, such as online banking, while connected to a public Wi-Fi network. Use a VPN for added security.
two-factor authentication: Enable two-factor authentication (2FA) on all your financial accounts. 2FA adds an extra layer of security by requiring a second form of verification, such as a text message code.
scam calls: Never provide personal or financial information over the phone unless you initiated the call. Scammers can spoof caller IDs to make it appear as though they are calling from a legitimate organization.
credit card safety: Use credit cards over debit cards for online purchases, as they offer better fraud protection. Regularly monitor your statements and report any suspicious activity immediately.
investment scams: Be cautious of investments that promise high returns with little risk. Always verify the credentials of the financial advisor and research the investment thoroughly before committing.
fraud detection: Regularly review your bank statements and credit reports for any unusual activity. Set up alerts with your bank to be notified of transactions over a certain amount.
email security: Use strong, unique passwords for your email accounts and enable two-factor authentication. Be wary of unsolicited emails asking for personal or financial information.
identity theft: To protect against identity theft, regularly monitor your credit report, shred documents containing personal information, and be cautious about sharing personal details online.
social media safety: Avoid sharing too much personal information on social media platforms. Scammers can use this information to guess your passwords or security question answers.
mobile banking: Ensure your banking apps are up-to-date and only download apps from official app stores. Use biometric authentication (like fingerprint or facial recognition) if available.
online banking: Always log out of your online banking session when finished. Avoid accessing your accounts on public computers or over public Wi-Fi.
data breaches: If your information is compromised in a data breach, immediately change your passwords and monitor your accounts for suspicious activity. Consider freezing your credit.
social engineering: Social engineering attacks trick you into revealing personal information. Always be cautious of unsolicited requests for your personal or financial details.
malware: Keep your computer and mobile devices updated with the latest security patches. Use antivirus software and avoid downloading files from unknown sources to protect against malware.
ransomware: Ransomware can encrypt your files and demand payment for their release. Back up your data regularly and avoid clicking on suspicious links or attachments.
fake websites: Verify the URL of the website before entering any personal information. Look for the padlock icon and ensure the site starts with HTTPS to confirm it's secure.
ATM safety: When using an ATM, be aware of your surroundings and shield your PIN. Use ATMs located inside banks whenever possible and avoid using ATMs in poorly lit or isolated areas.
tax scams: During tax season, be cautious of phishing emails or phone calls claiming to be from the IRS. The IRS will never demand immediate payment or ask for your credit card information over the phone.
charity scams: Scammers often exploit natural disasters or crises to solicit fake donations. Always research a charity before donating and be wary of unsolicited requests for donations.
cryptocurrency scams: Cryptocurrency investments can be highly speculative and are often targeted by scammers. Only invest in reputable cryptocurrencies and be cautious of schemes promising guaranteed returns.
wire transfer fraud: Be cautious when asked to wire money, especially to someone you don't know. Wire transfers are difficult to reverse, and scammers often use this method to steal funds.
job scams: Beware of job offers that require you to pay upfront fees or provide personal financial information. Research the company and job posting thoroughly before applying.
travel scams: Be cautious of travel deals that seem too good to be true. Scammers may offer fake vacation packages or rental properties. Always book through reputable travel agencies or platforms.
student loan scams: Scammers often target students with fake loan forgiveness programs or consolidation offers. Always research and verify any loan-related services before providing your information.
elder fraud: Elderly individuals are often targeted by scammers through phone calls, emails, or even in-person visits. Educate older family members about common scams and help them protect their financial information.
real estate scams: Be cautious when buying or renting property online. Scammers may create fake listings to collect deposits or personal information. Always verify the legitimacy of the property and deal with reputable agents.
romance scams: Scammers often use online dating sites to build fake relationships and solicit money. Be cautious of individuals who quickly profess love or ask for financial assistance.
gift card scams: Never pay for anything with a gift card unless you're purchasing it directly from a store. Scammers often ask for payment via gift cards because they are difficult to trace.
